feed.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT

entry.title: Re: Safer sighashes and more granular SIGHASH_NOINPUT
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the intricacies of Bitcoin script execution, particularly focusing on the `OP_CODESEPARATOR` and `OP_CHECKSIG` operations. The motivation behind the suggestion to deprecate `OP_CODESEPARATOR` stems from its requirement to recompute a new scriptCode for every call in conjunction with `OP_CHECKSIG`, as per BIP 143 guidelines. This process necessitates generating a new transaction digest each time, which was initially seen as problematic due to the perceived computational overhead.
The conversation also touches upon the issue of a potential combinatorial explosion in SIGHASH flag combinations, alongside the existing limitations on signature operations (SigOps). Despite these concerns, the argument is made that the cost associated with recomputing scriptCode using `OP_CODESEPARATOR` may not be as significant as previously thought. This reassessment suggests that the practical impact of retaining `OP_CODESEPARATOR` could be more manageable than its proposed removal.
Furthermore, it is highlighted that the use of `OP_CODESEPARATOR` might become unnecessary within certain scripting constructs due to the ability to "MASTify" more than 30 layers of sequential `OP_IF` statements. MAST (Merkelized Abstract Syntax Trees) provides a more efficient way to structure conditional execution in Bitcoin scripts, potentially obviating the need for `OP_CODESEPARATOR` within these limits. This insight points towards a direction where, despite the initial concerns, alternatives and optimizations may render the debate on `OP_CODESEPARATOR` less critical.
